content: The "Coeur d'Alene Basin Restoration Act of 1994" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act by adding a Coeur d'Alene Basin Management Conference. The Coeur d'Alene Basin Management Conference is established to develop a pollution prevention and restoration plan. The conference includes representatives from the EPA, Coeur d'Alene Indian tribe, and Idaho Department of Environmental Quality. Steering committees are appointed for management and technical advisory roles. The Management Conference establishes steering committees for advisory roles and includes ex officio members from the US House of Representatives. A pollution prevention and restoration plan must be published within a year. The Management Conference establishes steering committees for advisory roles and includes ex officio members from the US House of Representatives. A water pollution prevention, control, and restoration plan must be published within a year for the Coeur d'Alene Basin, clarifying duties and suggesting timetables for adoption by Federal and State agencies. The water pollution prevention and control plan for the Coeur d'Alene Basin must clarify duties, suggest timetables for adoption by Federal and State agencies, describe funding methods, incorporate environmental management concepts, and include a strategy for water pollution. The water pollution prevention and control plan for the Coeur d'Alene Basin must incorporate environmental management concepts, include a strategy for water pollution prevention, and undergo public review and comment. The Administrator, in cooperation with the Management Conference, shall provide for public review and comment on the draft Plan for the Coeur d'Alene Basin. The Plan must meet specific requirements and upon approval, it will be deemed an approved management program for water pollution prevention. Upon approval of the Plan for the Coeur d'Alene Basin, it will be considered an approved management program for water pollution prevention and a comprehensive conservation and management plan. Grant assistance may be provided for the development of the Plan. The Management Conference provides grants to water pollution control agencies and organizations for developing the Plan, with a federal share not exceeding 70% of the costs, and non-Federal share provided from non-Federal sources. The Administrator may set terms and conditions for the grants. The Management Conference provides grants for developing the Plan, with a federal share not exceeding 70% of the costs, and non-Federal share provided from non-Federal sources. The Administrator may establish terms and conditions for the grants. The term 'Coeur d'Alene Basin' is defined as a watershed in northern Idaho. Nothing in this section affects the jurisdiction or powers of any department or agency of the United States or any State. The Coeur d'Alene Basin in northern Idaho includes the South Fork of the Coeur d'Alene River, the main stem of the Coeur d'Alene River, and Lake Coeur d'Alene. The section does not impact the jurisdiction of any US or State department or agency, or any entity related to the Basin created by treaty. Appropriations are authorized for the Environmental Protection Agency for fiscal years 1995-1999. SEC. 3. FEDERAL PROGRAM COORDINATION. The Secretary of the Interior, in cooperation with the United States Geological Survey, will enhance data collection in the Coeur d'Alene Basin by developing an integrated geographic information system and converting partial recording sites to continuous monitoring stations. The Secretary of the Interior, in cooperation with appropriate departments and agencies of Idaho and Washington, will develop an integrated geographic information system in the Coeur d'Alene Basin, convert partial recording sites to continuous monitoring stations, and establish additional monitoring sites for data collection and monitoring. The United States Fish and Wildlife Service will also be involved in a resource conservation program. The Secretary of the Interior, in collaboration with the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, will establish a fisheries resources restoration program in the Coeur d'Alene Basin, focusing on hatchery production levels. The Secretary of the Interior, in collaboration with the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, will establish a fisheries resources restoration program in the Coeur d'Alene Basin, including dedicating hatchery production levels and conducting a wildlife species and habitat assessment survey. The Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service is authorized to carry out activities related to improving the health of fishery resources, including a survey of migratory bird populations in the Coeur d'Alene Basin. The Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service is authorized to carry out activities related to improving the health of fishery resources, conducting investigations, and updating a survey of fishery resources in the Coeur d'Alene Basin. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 1995-1999. The Director of the US Fish and Wildlife Service is authorized to conduct surveys of fishery resources in the Coeur d'Alene Basin. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 1995-1999. SEC. 4. RESTORATION PLAN. The Secretary of the Interior, through the Bureau of Land Management, will cooperate with other trustees to develop a restoration plan for public lands in the Coeur d'Alene Basin, including inventorying mining sites and contaminated areas. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act requires the development of a computerized inventory of abandoned mining sites in the Coeur d'Alene Basin, cleanup of contaminated areas, restoration of natural resources on public lands, and implementation of stream and river restoration plans. The Coeur d'Alene Basin restoration plan includes rebuilding stream structures, placing wood debris and habitat rocks, stabilizing banks, and planting riparian vegetation. Monitoring will assess restoration effectiveness and address any remaining issues. A land management plan will be developed collaboratively to reduce health and environmental risks in the Basin. The Coeur d'Alene Basin restoration plan involves developing a land management plan with various agencies to reduce health and environmental risks. Additionally, an integrated geographical information system will be maintained to coordinate management activities. Wildlife and fishery habitat management plans will also be created in collaboration with relevant organizations. The Coeur d'Alene Basin restoration plan includes developing wildlife and fishery habitat management plans with various agencies to ensure long-term coordinated management. This involves monitoring wildlife management areas for effectiveness and developing an integrated public recreation management plan to provide public information and minimize risks. The Coeur d'Alene Basin restoration plan involves collaborating with various agencies to develop an integrated public recreation management plan and implement a lake and river information program to provide public use and health risk information. The Bureau of Land Management is authorized to carry out activities related to data collection and inventory of mining waste source areas and contaminated lands. The Bureau of Land Management is authorized to carry out activities related to data collection, inventory of mining waste source areas, contaminated lands, resource information management, restoration activities, monitoring, design, construction, and maintenance of restoration projects and management facilities, and overseeing construction of repositories for mine waste and contaminated soil. The Bureau of Land Management is authorized to carry out activities related to human health and natural resource risks, restoration projects, mine waste repositories, lake and river information programs, long-term restoration and land management plans, and maintenance of restored public lands. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 1995-2002. SEC. 5. EXEMPTION FROM CERCLA LIABILITY. The EPA and DOI are exempt from liability under CERCLA for actions taken under this Act.
